This is a simple activity that you can during your warmup to review these graphemes and the rules that go with them. You can use this as a visual drill or auditory drill. 

Visual drill: choose a graphemes, say the sound it represents, then apply the “rule” to place it in the correct space. 

Auditory drill: say a sound. Find the two graphemes that represent those sound. (Can also have students write them on white boards.) Then, place it in the correct space to reinforce the rule. 

I actually did this the first time using my magnetic tiles that are always on my board. I just drew the chart real quick on the white board and we sorted them. But then I wanted a poster that I didn’t have to erase so I made this.

I added this fun activity to my gingerbread unit. I also updated the activities to make sure they are SoR aligned. You can find this one activity in the preview as a free sample!

This activity can be done in two ways:
 
1. Encoding/ word chain: Start anywhere on the board. Say the word and tap the sounds. Have students write the word on their individual white boards. Move the gingerbread man to the next spot. Say the word and determine which sound is different. Erase the letter that represents that sound, then write the new letter. 

2.  Decoding: Pick a word card. Cover the picture that represents that sound. 

I added different options of boards for option #2 (blends, silent e, vowel teams, and two syllable words).

One of my groups started practicing reading two-syllable words with at least one silent e syllable. This is a great way to start. First we read each syllable and point out which syllable type it is. Then, we start with one syllable and find the second syllable match that makes a real word. 

Then, I took that opportunity to show how to expand the words with different suffixes.

Our brains have evolved to be wired for speech and language, but they are not wired for reading. Reading is not a natural process. Our students’ brains are being rewired as they learn to read. (So cool, right?!) For some kids, this process comes a little easier. For others, it takes more effort. Keeping this in mind is super important. 💕

More fun with words with a Polar Express theme.  Since a conductor drives the train, it thought it who’d be fun to dive deeper into the word “conductor” by learning more about its root and relatives. Since “duct” means “to lead” (like it’s brother “Duce”, you can ask your students how that explains the meaning of the word “conductor”. 

Break the word up by finding the prefixes and suffixes. Then, brainstorm words that have the same root. Build your matrix with your students, then show them how to connect them to make different words. 

Side note: “Duce” is like a brother to “duct” as far as I can tell (you use duct for production and duce for produce.) They both come from the Latin “ducere”, meaning to lead. It looks like verbs use the “duce” and nouns or adjectives use “duct” but I don’t know if that’s a “rule”. If anyone has more info, would love to hear in the comments. :) 

Another fun fact that I think is pretty consistent is that if the base ends with <ct>, you will usually use suffix -or instead of the more common -er. That helps me (as a not great speller) remember to use -or.

Forgot to post this earlier! My students LOVE word hunts. This one incorporates decoding and encoding. 

(I also have these word hunts for any time of year- not with gingerbread people. So far I have short vowels and silent e and working on the rest!)

Place the gingerbread around the room. Students will find them and decode the words on them. They will say the word and use it in a sentence. Next they will go back to their desk where their student sheet is waiting. They will find the matching picture and write the word on the next to that picture (encoding).

To help students make connections about words and really understand syllable types within multi-syllable words, I sometimes mix in an activity like this. When I was first learning about all this, I was confused about the lingo and how it all fit together. I was confused about the difference between syllable types and syllable division. I didn’t quite get it. This activity is meant to show students how it all goes together. 

 I start working on syllable types right away. I introduce the term “closed syllables” in kindergarten when I introduce VC and CVC words.  Then I introduce open syllables, silent e syllables, vowel team syllables, bossy r syllables, and consonant -le syllables. I want students to understand that there are different syllable types. Understanding syllable types helps with understanding which vowel sound to use and why. 

When we move into reading multi-syllable words, I introduce syllable division, which is a strategy for decoding these words. 

Once a word is divided into its syllable parts, we look at each syllable and see what type is syllable it is. That is what this activity is doing.

#morphology

I’ve talked before about how English is morphology-phonemic, meaning both phonology (sound-symbol) and morphology (structure of a word) play equal roles. When looking at a word, sometimes looking at sound-symbol relationships makes the most sense, while in other cases you need to look at the morphology, too. 

There are so many words that appear to not make any sense when you just look at phonology (how sounds and letter match up). Instead an explanation for a random letter may have to do with etymology (history of a word) and/or it’s morphology or word relatives. 

In the word “people”, there are two letters that seem out of place. The <e> at the end is easily explained by syllable types. The <e> is part of the syllable type “Consonant +le”. The e is there because every syllable ke needs a written vowel. (I have a blog post all about syllable types. If you’re interested, please message me.) 

The <o> is a little trickier, but super interesting. I learned from Pete Bowers (Google him to learn more about Structured Word Inquiry) that possibly the <o> is there to mark its relation to the word “population”. When I looked on etymonline I saw that is came from the Latin word “populus” so that also explains the <o>! 

So when you’re teaching your students this word, it can be fun to give them all the tools, including these fun little tidbits. I don’t expect them to remember it but it’s fun to talk about words and their stories!

.
.
.
.
.

Once I learned this rule, I started to see it everywhere! Some other common words with this <e> are choose, horse, house, pause, raise, rinse, please, and loose. Those are just the first to pop in my mind. There’s so many more. Even though this is a tricky concept, it’s helpful to know why the <e> is there. This is one of the many jobs of silent e. Can you think of any other words?

If you’ve followed me for a while, you’ve seen pumpkins, ghosts, clovers, trees, hearts, and suns fill in words representing various various sounds (whatever I’m working on at that moment). I have these scattered in various literacy packs, but I decided to put them all in one place. 

This activity is great for a group activity (putting words on chart paper or projecting words) or as an independent activity. You can focus on decoding (finding words that are real or not) or you can make it an automaticity activity where you decode a few times using different vowel fillers.

This is an activity that I did after I introduced consonant -le and had practiced how to do syllable division with this syllable type.  I wanted to help them see how syllable division with consonant -le words can be so helpful since it’s so consistent. 

This could also be done as a less guided activity. You could write all the words (in one color) and shuffle them. Choose one word at a time. Have students look at the word and decide what column is correct for that word. 

A few facts about consonant -le syllable type:
* It’s only found in multi-syllable word. It’s never a word on its own.
* It only comes at the end of a word. 
* It doesn’t have a distinct vowel sound (you can kind of hear a schwa sound when you combine the consonant sound with /l/.)
* The <e> is there because every syllable must have a written vowel. It is one of the many jobs of silent e. 

I’ll post more info in my stories soon. 

.
.
.
.

Giving corrective feedback is an essential component of literacy instruction. No matter what stage they are at, there is usually some corrective feedback involved. It’s just part of the process and it’s what helps our students grow.  I made this video a few days ago and since then, I’ve decided the real reason for the error was the second thing I talked about more so than the first. 

I think it’s a phonemic issue because I’ve noticed it with other words where the last sound is substituted. I still think it was worth pointing out the sound similarities between /k/  and /g/, but it turns out he second strategy I used has been the most effective and helpful for this particular scenario. 

I learned that I need to shift my focus to phoneme isolation focusing on the last sound. Next week, I plan on doing that activity for my phonemic awareness warm-up each day. I will say a word, we will stretch it and tap/enunciate the last sound. If needed, I’ll do it first then have them repeat. 

.
.
.
.
.

This is a great word sort and different than the usual word sorts because they have to actually read the word and/or apply the generalization. These words all look the same in that they are all closed syllables that end with consonant blends. However, some have long vowels and some short vowels. Words ending in -ost, -olt, -old, -ind, and -ild are usually closed syllable exceptions because the vowel is usually long. This is often referred to as “Wild Old Words”. (-ost is a little sketchy though because cost, lost, and frost all do have short vowels but “most”, “host” and “post” all have a long vowels.) 

When I teach this generalization, I do start with phoneme-grapheme mapping, pointing out the fact that the vowels are long even though it is a closed syllables. Then, I transition them into seeing the rimes as a unit or chunk so they can recognize them in words. In other words, I point out that “old” does have three distinct sounds represented by three letters but it may be easier to try to remember the chunk or unit “old” instead of sounding it out, since it is a “rule breaker” with a long vowel. We do a lot of practice reading and spelling  words with these endings. This activity is more of a follow up to review these endings and other similar endings that do not follow that “rule”. 

This can be done in a guided setting or can be a center done independently. When I do it in a small group, I also use it as an informal assessment to see if the group is ready to move on.

Right now my focus with one of my groups is developing automaticity at the word level and fluency at the sentence level. I have taught cvc words, digraphs, and blends with short vowels (and also suffix s, es, ed , and ing) so far. Before moving on to the next skill, I want to give them more time with connected text. 

I have a video from last year on my YouTube channel. If you’re interested in hearing more about this activity, I can message you the link to that video. 

I taught my students that a phrase is a group of words that go together. It is not usually a complete sentence but is part of a sentence. 

The worksheet page with the phrases is part of the student “workbook” in my Systematic Phonics Instruction unit 1.

I’ve been asked a few times whether I use successive blending or if I focus on onset and rime. The answer is both! I use successive blending when the issue is phoneme blending. I also spend time on rimes (the vowel and everything after it) also called word families. I think this helps when students are slower decoders or stuck at the sound by sound phase. I think focusing on rimes helps our struggling or beginning readers because they start to recognize those familiar rimes. The hope is that they “map” the rime so they can be more fluent when decoding words with that rime. 

I didn’t mention this in the video but I think both strategies are good for improving accuracy and for kids who tend to want to guess. 

A common problem I see with early readers is saying the last sound incorrectly. Successive blending really comes in handy with this. I like to show them how many words begin with the same two letters. I’ll start with those two letters, blend them, and then show the last letter. Then I’ll replace the last letter. For example, we’ll read sat, sap, sag, and sad. This helps show them the importance  of reading the whole word, every sound.

I’m working on decoding and spelling two syllable words with all syllable types with one of my groups. (Previously, we had worked on just open and close syllable types. Now we’re working on words with as least one syllable that has silent e, vowel teams or bossy r.) 

We started to notice some common first syllables, which are also common prefixes.  I decided to group them and make a list for each. There are more than you see here of course, but I wanted to show my students how common they are and then show them how helpful it is to look for these common prefixes when reading. Some students will make these connections on their own but other students need us to help make those connections. It was super helpful to group these words and then practice reading and spelling words that begin with these prefixes. At the very least, this helps with decoding. 

I went one step further and picked some words to build bigger by adding suffixes. This shows kids they could read and spell really big words like “detection” or detective” or “undetected”. This will also set them up for later when they go deeper into morphology. We also pointed out common 2nd syllables (which are roots) like “fect ” in “defect” and “infect”. After that we built word matrices (parts of them anyway) to as many words as I could think of with that root. It’s just amazing to see how many connections you can make with words. When I think  I’m just doing a lesson on syllable division, it turns into all this which feels so much more thorough and interesting. :)

This is a simple game that kids love. Each set has a different phonics focus, but all have a fall, winter, spring, and “anytime” theme included to give students practice reading rimes, words, and phrases. 

To use in a small group setting: Give each student a board. Pass the spinner so students take turns being the one that spins. Announce what they landed on. Have students put their chip in the row that has that picture. You can read together in unison or you can have kids whisper read to themselves. I like to do a combo, changing it up as the game goes. 

You can also do this whole group by projecting the board. Have students take turns spinning the spinner and being the person who uses a pointer and leading the class to read that row. 

This can also be used as a center or parter game. 

While I’m using the rime board, I like to ask questions like, “What ending would you use to spell the word tent?” Then I’d instruct students to place their chip on the circle under the rime to show their answer.

Here is an example of how morphology can help us understand the spelling of a word, especially when the pesky schwa is involved! 

A few other notes:

* the base element “side” (meaning to sit) is bound because it is not a word by itself. It only becomes a word when other morphemes (prefixes or suffixes) are added to it. (This is different than the free base word “side” meaning left or ride side.) 

* a schwa sound is the most common vowel sound and any letter can represent a schwa sound. It comes in the unstressed syllable of a word. As you add prefixes and suffixes, the schwa may move because the stressed syllable moves. An example of that is preside to president to presidential. The <i> spells a schwa sound in president but also the e (in -ent) sort of does too. But in presidential you can hear that e in -ent much more clearly. 

This information comes from Sue Hegland in Learning about Spelling.

Long u can be tough especially because there are two sounds associated with it: /yu/ as in “few” and /u/ as in “cool”. Long u is first introduced during my silent e  unit with u-consonant- e words. Then, I revisit more ways to spell it with vowel teams. 

First I introduce the different vowel teams that spell the long u sound (I haven’t introduced <ou> yet). I spend the most time on <oo> and <ew> because those are more common. There are only a few single syllable words with <ue> and <ui> (and they are shown here). 

During the word sort, students are focusing on decoding. There are two ways I’ve done this. You can show a card, give students time to decode on their own, then read together. Or you can give each student in your small group a card to read to the group and then place in the chart. After reading the card, ask them what letters spell the long u sound. Then, place it in the chart. With this, we’re reinforcing the graphemes that spell the long u sound. 

Next, we look at where each grapheme is used. <ew> and <ue> are used at the end of words but <ew> is more common. (Remember these are generalizations. There are a couple words with <ew> not at the end.) <ui> is only in the middle of a few words. <oo> is mostly used in the middle but can he found at the end of a few words and in the beginning for a couple. Again, a generalization that can be helpful. Next, I show all the other <oo> words to show frequency.

Last, we work on spelling. I say a word then ask them to point to the options based on the position of the long u sound. Then they show me which one they think it is before writing the word and I correct as needed. 

I kept these words in the pocket chart for a while so we could reread the words as an automaticity activity.

*This format for creating word matrix and word sums comes from Pete Bowers. He has a great website full of information. 
 
I love showing kids the words you can make by adding different prefixes and suffixes. I don’t expect my young students to remember rules like suffix -y creating an adjective but I do think it’s an interesting tidbit to point out. It’s interesting to see how adding suffixes can change the function of a word! 

While I do this, I’ll orally create sentences. For example, “He has good luck”  and “Today is my lucky day!” I’ll point out that in the second sentence the word “lucky” described my day. I’m the first sentence luck was a thing that he had. 

I had already taught the changing rule but it’s always a tricky one so it’s great to have the opportunity to focus on it again. It’s first introduced when I show them how to add suffix -ed to single syllable words like “try” (they need to drop the y, change it to i and then add the suffix -ed.) They also learn that you use this rule with all suffixes except -ing because you never want two i’s next to each other. Later when we get into vowel teams they learn this rule doesn’t apply to words that have a vowel sound before the y (like “play”). 

I don’t expect kids to memorize anything I’m doing at this point but I find value in showing them the breakdown of words and how they work.

This is a simple activity to practice short vowel sounds. It’s a great warm up activity. These bookmarks are a free resource in my store. 

I usually get a comment telling me not to use the word elephant as a keyword so I want to be clear that I do not use elephant as a keyword. The word “elephant” is not a good keyword to use because the short e sound gets combined with the /l/ sound and it’s hard to pull apart. You don’t hear that short e sound very distinctly. I use the word “Eddie”. I make this whole production when I focus on short e introducing Eddie the elephant and how he wants to be called by his name. It’s never been a problem with any of my students and I’ve been using a version of this bookmark for many years now. We always do the “Eddie, Eddie, /e/ /e/ /e/“ chant so much so they never accidentally say “elephant”. I hope this helps clear up any confusion. :)

After teaching the dropping rule, I always want to spend a little more time practicing decoding silent e words with suffixes. It’s usually easier to remember the rule while spelling but seems harder to remember with decoding. How do we know the difference between hoping and hopping? Look at the consonants between the vowel and suffix. If there is one consonant, the vowel is likely a long vowel and if there are two consonants the vowel is likely a short vowel. With “hoping”, the base word is “hope” and the silent e is dropped before adding a vowel suffix like -ing or -Ed. With “hopping”, the base word is “hop” and the

was doubled before adding the vowel suffix to show that the vowel is short. This activity helped with that rule because each time they looked at a word, I reminded them to check the consonants between the vowel and the suffix. (Note that I only used vowel suffixes. Consonant suffixes don’t drop the silent e and do not double the consonant either.) After sorting all the words, we took another look at the words to verify this generalization.

It’s been a while since I’ve posted one of these. I think this illustrates how complex and interesting words can be. It’s so important to teach those foundational skills, beginning with sounds and connecting to symbols. Just as soon as kids start decoding words, I start introducing morphology in the most basic way with suffix -s (then suffixes -es, -Ed, and -ing). I don’t choose one or the other (phonology or morphology). I choose both! :) Fast forward to second/third grade and I’m still teaching sound-symbol relationships but now it’s vowels teams and diphthongs. At the same time, I’m pointing out more and more prefixes and suffixes. Recognizing common affixes (prefixes or suffixes) is so helpful with reading unknown words. They are using decoding skills to figure out the base or root then they can add on those affixes. Sometimes there are no affixes, so being able to break up a word comes in handy. I want to give them all the tools! It doesn’t happen overnight. :) The more I learn, the more I can pass along to my students. 

Some would see this word and would have success decoding by syllable. Others would see the morphemes and figure it out that way. All of this is to say, as teachers it’s helpful to gain knowledge about all the things: phonology, orthography, and morphology. But like our students, it won’t happen overnight and that’s okay, too! But I will say, it sure is fun to learn! I’ve been digging in for years and still tweaking/adding things and learning all the time. I still say “Im not sure”
Or “I don’t know” quite a bit! 😅 

(Speaking of, I’m not quite sure how to correctly label sounds like /er/ for example. I know the sounds but not always how to show them in writing.)

I’ve had a few questions come up recently about the schwa. The schwa sound is actually the most common vowel sound. It is a softer, lazier /u/ sound and sometimes a short /I/ sound. The schwa sound could be used with any vowel letter. It is the result of us not enunciating every single syllable equally. We don’t pronounce “lemon” like lem-on (with a short o sound). We usually say “lemin” or “lemun”. Once you introduce the schwa, they start to notice it everywhere!

I used to wait longer before introducing the schwa but now I feel like it’s unavoidable when you begin reading and spelling multi-syllable words. The schwa explains so much and kids really do get it. I don’t need them to remember the terminology but I want them to get the concept. I also want them to have flexility when they are decoding. If the expected vowel sound doesn’t work then I want them to be able to adjust. 

Although there is no way to know exactly when or where a schwa sound will pop up (especially since accents will affect pronunciation), there are a few generalization that help. 

*When a word begins with the letter <a> and it is an open syllable on its own (meaning its the only letter in the syllable), the <a> usually represents the schwa sound. (a-round, a-bout, a-way, a-gain) 

* When a word ends in the letter <a>, that letter usually represents the schwa sound (data, banana, umbrella). Again, it’s an open syllable (because it ends with a vowel) but it doesn’t make the long a sound. Usually if you want to spell the long a sound at the end of a word, you use <ay>. It’s pretty safe to say when you see a word ending in just <a>, it will make the schwa sound. 

* Lots of times when a multi-syllable word ends with -on or -an, the <o> or <a> will represent a schwa sound. (Lemon, bacon, ribbon, human) 

* When a word ends with vowel then <l>, the vowel is often barely audible and makes an /ul/ sound. This is a very lazy and quiet schwa sound! (Camel, nickel, dental)

This is a simple activity you can recreate using any decodable sentence (depending on the phonics pattern or grapheme you’re working on). You can write it on the white board or put it on sentence strips. It’s meant to get kids rereading the same sentence over and over, filling in different word options. This is for students who are stuck at the point where they can decode a word slowly, but sentences are a big challenge. 

It’s not unusual at all for kindergarten students to sit in this phase for a while with cvc words. They have mastered sound-symbol associations with the 26 letters of the alphabet and can decode and spell cvc and vc words with accuracy. But they may need weeks to practice decoding so they can be more automatic at the word level, then the phrase and sentence level. Some kids are ready to jump into reading decodable books but others may need more activities like this one before they are ready for reading sentences independently. Some other things that also help kids in this stage are decodable sentence scramblers, sentence pyramids, and decodable phrases.

This week one of my groups focused on suffixes -ful, -less, and -ly. I started with -ful and -less together because so many base words can use both. These are pretty easy suffixes because they mean exactly what you’d predict they would mean. 

First, we looked at words where the suffixes are just added to words with no changes (helpful/helpless, careful/careless, aimless, tearful). Because these are consonant suffixes (they begin with an consonant ), you don’t need to do any dropping when words end in silent e (as opposed to vowel suffixes where you do need to drop the e). With each word, I also review phonics rules. I might ask which syllable type was used for the base word or what letters spell a certain vowel sound. 

Next, I threw in words that ended with -y so we could practice dropping the y and changing to i before adding the suffixes (penniless, plentiful). This is a concept that has been introduced a couple times already but it’s a tough one so I love being able to review this rule! (I first introduce it first with y as a vowel spelling long i when you turn “try” into “tried” or “fly” into “flies”. Then I reviewed it when they were learning about y spelling long e at the end of multi syllable words like “baby” to “babies”.) 

Next, I introduce -ly. These three suffixes work nicely together because there’s a lot of words where you can add -ful + -ly or -less + -ly. By this point, they’ve definitely seen these suffixes and we’ve even briefly talked about them as they’ve come up in texts. But now is when I dive a little deeper with explicit teaching and dedicated practice time. 

We practice encoding and decoding: I start by saying a word, then break it into its morphemes to spell it. We identify the base then the suffixes. Then, I write the word and look for the morphemes to determine the base word. Either way, I write out the word in “expanded form” (it’s not called that, but that’s what it reminds me of anyway). So for example, “penniless” is penny + less. Then I cross out the y and change it to i and then write it again as “penniless”. 

I hope this is helpful!

This makes spelling make so much more sense and I think it’s actually interesting to break down words. It makes them so much less intimidating. This seems like a lot but everything we did here has already been taught with other words. We learned the drop e rule back when I taught silent e words and we had to add suffix -Ed and -ing. We learned the change y rule first when learning y represents long i like in fly or try and we had to add suffixes to those words. We learned it again when we were working with two syllable words ending in y (baby, penny) that had suffixes added to them. Students rarely master these suffix rules the day you teach them because they are complicated. But they keep coming up again and again. The drop e and change y rules came up a lot when teaching suffixes -ful, -less, and -ly this week. Also a bonus was that it was a great time to review phonics skills we’ve taught as well! I could review syllable types and vowel combinations with the base words. I could also review decoding and spelling of two syllable words. I hope to get these lesson plans added to my units soon. I just wanted to practice them and do them first before adding them in! 😅 I’ll be adding lessons about these suffixes into the unit 5 vowel teams lessons.

I like to have ready to go pieces to use to make my teaching or guided practice more interactive. You can call on a student to choose the syllable types or label the pattern. Sometimes I only use the V pieces because it’s all about the vowels! Some kids don’t need to go through all the syllable division rules and but pointing out the vowels is always helpful and a good habit. This is a scaffold- the goal is to not have to do all of these steps while decoding. 

This word isn’t the best example because after decoding a few words that begin with “con”, I point out that this is a common prefix that they’ll see in many words. If they see <con> they don’t really have to through all the steps because it’s pretty much always going to be divided after <con>. But it’s good to have lots of ways to decode, right? 

This word also have a schwa - the <o> represents the schwa sound. That’s not all that uncommon for <con>, though. Once students have read each syllable and put it together to read the word, they usually figure out it’s pronounced “cuntain” not “cOntain”.

Here are a few slides looking into the word “recycle”. 

Phonics concepts: 
* <c> spells /s/ when <i>, <e>, or <y> follows. 

* <y> spells long i sound. 

* The silent e is at the end of the word because it is part of the consonant -le syllable type. (Every syllable needs a written vowel and this syllable doesn’t have an distinct vowel sound. One of the many jobs of e!) 

Morphology concepts: 
* Prefix re- means “again”.

* Cycle is a base element that can create several other words. It is Greek in origin and means “circle”. 

* When adding different suffixes to this word, the silent e is dropped when it’s a vowel suffix (so all but the suffix -s). 

It’s fun to take a big word like “recyclable” and break down the three morphemes: re+cycle+able. Then you can ask, “What happened to the <e> in cycle when you added that suffix?”

I’ve been adding more and more to our morphology board! I use this with my second and third grade groups. 

In most cases, a prefix or suffix is added after I’ve done a lesson on them but a few of them have been added because we have seen them in so many words! For example, I haven’t done a lesson for the prefixes “con”, “ex” and “com” but they came up SO much when we were working on syllable division with two syllable words. They are very familiar with them now! 

The blue base words are just a few examples of words we’ve used to build a word matrix or that we used when introducing a suffix. We could have a ton of blue words up there but I just added a few up there and can change them out. 

The roots are added once we’ve actually gone into that root by building different words with various prefixes and suffixes (usually with a word matrix). The exception there is “cede/ceed ”. We didn’t build a full matrix but we noticed it while doing syllable division activities. After reading proceed and exceed, one of my students said, “ceed must be a root!” We took a few minutes to to look into it (it’s meaning and any other common words with it), so we thought we’d add it to the wall. 

Basically, the wall it a record of affixes and roots that we’ve learned about or seen often enough. It’s amazing how much my second grade students truly get it! Now I often hear them saying, “Is that a root?” Or “I see a prefix!” I laid the groundwork in first grade with base words and the most common suffixes. 

I’m still learning as I go, but I love incorporating morphology into my reading and spelling instruction. I’ve noticed so much progress and a true deeper understanding of the structure of words.

We are finishing up bossy r in 2nd grade and I wanted to make it a full review with other syllable types and random phonics generalizations, too (that I have taught some point this year). This would also be great for third graders!

An oldie but a goodie! This game is great with a small group, partner game, or even whole class (divide the class in half). I use magnets as game pieces. 
*
So here’s how to play with a group. Kids take turns rolling the die. I point to the number they rolled and give the signal so they all make the sound. Then we move the little magnetic person along the board. You combine the sound you rolled with the word endings and stop when you get to a real word. 
*
For example, if you roll 2 and you’re at the start, you would point to the p by the dice and say /p/ then point to the first space and say the sounds together “aaaaaap”. Repeat /p/ /aaaaap/. Say the word “pap”. Ask, “Is that a word?” Nope! Keep going. Do the same with the next. Once you get to a real word, your turn is over. 
*
As a warm up, you can go around the game board and just read the word endings. This is a great automaticity activity, too! 
*
This example shows cvc words, but you could do the same for other phonics skills, too. 
*
Side note : This is too long to finish in one sitting but that’s what’s so great about the little magnets.  You could leave this on your white board and come back to it throughout the day or week! 
*
I also have a digital version, which is way less prep, but I don’t have a projector in my current classroom. (You can swipe to see it.) You can project it onto your screen then use the moveable pieces to go along the board. You can find the game on the next slide in my Phonics Games Pack: CVC words.

This was a good way to review long vowel teams with a small group. For each word, we would say the word, then I’d ask for the vowel sound. Next I’d ask which letter combinations can spell that sound. Last, I’d call on someone to choose the correct grapheme to go fill in the word. For long a or long o, I’d ask them how they knew which one to choose. This would give them the opportunity  to repeat their learning (for example, in “boat”, you’d choose <oa> and not <ow> because of the position of the long i sound. When it’s in the middle, use <oa>).

I did this game with a small group of students. They have learned the graphemes ai, ay, oa, ow, igh, ea, and we so far. They needed a little guided practice with all of the new graphemes together so they could practice matching sound to new symbols. Here are a few things I did to make sure they were getting the most out of it. 

After a team rolled the die and said a sound, I asked “Which graphemes can spell that sound?” The group an answer. Then I would say take a moment to look at all of these words and decide what your choices are for that vowel sound. Next, I would ask them which word they wanted to cover keeping in mind they wanted to eventually get five in a row. This way, they were reading and re-reading words and getting opportunities to decode on their own. There were even opportunities for corrective feedback. For example, when one group rolled long i, I heard somebody choose a word that had<ai>. I was able to give the corrective feedback, and then use that opportunity to review the graphemes that spell long i. 

another way that I got them to read and reread words, but once they got two words in a row or three words in a row, I would ask that group to read the words that they have so far in a row. 

if they had only one or two left in a row, I might ask that group what do you hope to roll? Why? 

It doesn’t work every time to get five in a row. Sometimes a team would block another team so that nobody ended up getting five and a row. But that’s OK cause it’s all part of the game :-)

I just added another Google slides option to by digraph decodable sentence strips. I’m working on adding the same to the other sets as well. This set of slides is for those students who are decoding accurately but very slowly. We want to get some practice decoding within connected text, but this can be very difficult for our beginning or struggling readers. If they are sounding out every single word, without going back to restart the sentence, then most likely the meaning is lost. From the very beginning, we want to send a message that we are sounding out these words for a reason. These aren’t just words written on a page so we can send them out. The words come together in a sentence to make meaning. Then the sentences on a page come together for an overall story or message from the author. I find that this activity really helps to encourage my students to have better habits when learning to read. 

If you already own this, make sure you download this new addition! I’ll be adding the updates to the others soon. I’ll leave a link in my profile to these sentence strips or you can comment below and I’ll message you the link.

This lesson did five things:

1) Introduced the new graphemes <au> and <aw>. 
2) Provided opportunities to practice decoding words with au and aw. It also gave me teachable moments while giving corrective feedback. 
3) Taught the spelling generalization for au/aw in an engaging way. (Students love to “solve” this)
4) I was able to review the graphemes <se> and <ce> for spelling /s/ and /z/. 
5) Introduced the homophones “pause” and “paws” while reviewing the plural canceling rule. 

The lesson for teachers is that it’s never JUST a word sort. 🤣

This is more of an informative video for teachers, not necessarily an exact lesson I’d do for students. I do however teach my students both morphology and syllable division. I like to show them both ways of looking at a word. Often when we come across a word, I will do this for that word (show them how to divide it by syllable/how it sounds and show them the root and affixes.) I know I didn’t go into the how for syllable division in this video, so if you are interested in that, please let me know. Happy to go through those steps in another video. I teach my students that every time they see <tion>, that is always a syllable that is pronounced “shun”. For bigger words, it’s often easier to just be flexible with how sounds as you are decoding it. I think the more you go into morphology and the more affixes students know, the easier it gets to look at a word in that way. At the same time, sometimes it just easier to use syllable division.

This poster can be used in a couple of different ways. I initially used it as an activity where we placed the sticky notes in the correct spot. But then I kept it up for students to refer to while we practiced spelling. Vowel teams are hard particularly with spelling so it’s nice to have a chart to refer to. Please note: There are always exceptions. These are generalizations.

Once you’ve taught  a high frequency word to your students using phoneme-graphemes mapping, then your student will most likely need to read and write that word a few more times before it becomes a “sight” word. On average, a student needs 4-14 exposures before a word is automatically recognized “on sight”. However, this number can be much higher for students with dyslexia. (For students with dyslexia, it could take 40+ exposures, and in my experience, it feels like a lot more than that sometimes.) 

So, although phoneme graphemes mapping is essential for word recognition, so is repetition. I’ve made sentences for high frequency words (grouped by phonic skill). This way, kids can practice decoding, sentence reading, and have a target high frequency word. These are not new to my store, but they used to be part of a bigger pack and now they are also a stand-alone resource.

This is so important to keep in mind! We shouldn’t wait until third grade to start focusing on fluency. It begins in kindergarten! 

Fluency begins with letters and sounds. Students must become automatic with identifying the sound associated with the letter but they also need to become comfortable with phoneme blending and segmenting. 

Next we build toward automatic word recognition, which happens through orthographic mapping. This can be facilitated with explicit phonics instruction. I even think about decoding as having it’s own fluency spectrum. Just think- some kids decode with ease and smoothness while others are slow and laborious with decoding. 

Once students get comfortable decoding at the word level, we can move to the phrase and sentence level. Some kids are ready to jump into sentences but usually my intervention kiddos benefit from some time reading and spelling at the phrase level first. 

Last is the passage level. With passages or books, there is more punctuation to attend to and other things that influence how we read the text. Prosody/ expression  become more of a focus here as well. 

I talk about this and a lot more in my presentation coming up with @theeducatorsummit . Comment below if you’d like the link to more information. I’m one of 33 presenters for this k-2 conference! 

If you’re not interested in the conference but want to learn more about this post, please feel free to message me! I’m on summer break and have a bit more time now. :)

Often when I’m first introducing consonant blends, I don’t necessarily jump right to reading sentences and decodable book on the first day because often they need a little more time to practice at the word level and the phrase level.

This lesson plan can look very different depending on the student. 

For example, if I’m working with a student who is still at the phase where they are sounding out every single word slowly but accurately, I would try to do more repetition for the student. I would probably spell the same words that the student just decoded. I would create phrases based on the words that the student already  decoded or spelled. Instead of reading a decodable book, I would spend more time with simple sentences, modeling rereading the sentence after sounding out a word. This student didn’t need as much as that so instead I focused on fluency (reading in phrases and using expression). 

If I’m working with a student who has weak phonemic awareness skills, then I would spend more time blending &segmenting 2 consonants together. For example, I would show the the letter sp then have the student say each sound sounds, then blend those sounds together and think of a word that begins with that blend. I would also do the opposite. I would say “st” then have them break the two sounds apart pushing bingo chips as they say /s/ /t/. Then we would write the letters st. For students  with extreme difficulty with phoneme blending and segmenting, separating and blending two  consonant sounds can be very difficult. 

One thing I didn’t do in this lesson, but will do it in the next one is focus on high frequency words that have consonant blends. Will work on decoding & spelling those words, and reading/spelling  them within connected text.

More fun with words! The word “independent” has 4 morphemes (smallest unit of meaning in a word).

The Latin root “pend” means “to hang” or “to weigh”. The variant spelling is “pens”. 

The website Membean is so helpful when looking at how the meanings of roots relate to the meaning of words. A few examples: When you are dependent on a person, you hang from them and when you are independent you do not hang from anyone or anything. (The prefix in- means “not” or the opposite of.). When something is pending, it is hanging in limbo. A pendant hangs from your neck. Check out membean for more info!

Another site I use is etymonline. You can learn about the history of a word and its roots. 

I was interested to see that “dependent” can also be spelled like “dependant” which is the French spelling. I am always getting confused when spelling suffixes -ant vs -ent and -ance vs -ence. I never remember whether to use an <a> or an <e>. 😅 It turns out there’s a reason for my confusion! It has to do with Latin and French influences. Old French changed a lot of words ending with -ent to -ant and then many of the words changed back again. 🤪 I’ve seen generalizations here and then about when to use one or the other but it is way too complicated and I’ve never been able to remember them. Thankfully it’s easy to look words up when I need to!

I made this a while ago but never posted it. Hope it’s helpful! I’m definitely in summer mode right now but still want to give some helpful content! Hope you’re all enjoying your summers!

Simple activity for practicing ways to spell ending /j/ sound. I teach this with my silent e unit. One of the jobs of silent e is to “make the <g> soft”. When <e> follows <g>, it signals the reader that the <g> will likely represent the “soft” sound /j/. You can think of <ge> as a grapheme that represents the /j/ sound. 

Another grapheme that represents the /j/ sound is <dge>. <dge> is only used right after a short vowel sound. Otherwise, you use <ge>. (So after a long vowel sound or consonant, <ge> is used). 

You can do this activity in a couple different ways: 

Easiest: You can say the words and have students choose the correct endings based on the sound before the /j/ sound. They will simply practice applying the rule in the most basic way. 

Another way to do it is to have them try to decode the word. In this case you would tell them when a vowel is short or long. You would also tell them the blank space is always /j/ but they need to figure out the spelling. For example, the word lo____ isn’t clear whether the o would be short or long. You could tell them short and then they could decode /l/ /o/ /j/ and choose the correct spelling. 

Most challenging/my favorite:  It’s tricky but fun to actually try to figure out the vowel sound! This makes it a decoding activity where you place the <dge> and the <ge> in the blank space and then decode the word. (So you end up decoding two different words-one with short vowel and one with long- and choose which is correct.) In this way they have to apply the rule knowing that if you inserted <ge> in the blank space, then the vowel would be long. They would then figure out “loge” isn’t a word.  Then you would insert <dge>, knowing the vowel sound is short when it comes before <dge> and you could decode “lodge”. Words like hin___ are easier because it has to be <ge>. However it’s still a good reminder that <dge> never follows a consonant. This is super interactive and full of teachable moments!  After figuring out the word, always connect to meaning by defining the word or using it in a sentence.

Here are two examples of the same assessment. This is an assessment I would give after teaching a unit- in this case long vowel teams. You can learn a lot from this: 

1. Are they applying the new skills that I just  taught them? (If not, this is not a skill they have yet so I need to reteach and give more opportunities to apply their learning in spelling and reading.)

2. Are they continuing to demonstrate knowledge of past phonics concepts?

3. What are they doing when they get to an unknown word? (Guessing, skipping, decoding but inaccurately, decoding accurately)

4. When they do decode a word, how are they doing it? Are they decoding grapheme by grapheme, onset and rime, or somewhere in the middle? Are they making specific errors like substituting a different vowel sound,  making an error on a specific grapheme, or blending the sounds incorrectly? 

5. Are there words that were read automatically? Is this number increasing or is this a roadblock? (Are they having to sound out most words?)

6. Are they reading fluently? Pay attention to pace, phrasing, expression, attention to punctuation. Are they still reading word by word even though they recognize the words? (They are not putting words together into meaningful phrases.) 

Based on the answers to these questions I adjust my instruction. In some cases, I may need to spend more time on a specific phonics concept or phoneme-graphemes relationship. In other cases, I can move on.  Sometimes I may want to spend a little more time on that unit I’m working on to give them time to improve fluency and automaticity with word recognition. 

I hope this is helpful! Leave me a comment if you’d like the link to my phonics assessments.

One of my favorite activities when teaching the letters of the alphabet is an initial sound sort. This requires students to identify the first sound of the word, then match that sound to the correct letter. It’s a great way to get some repetitive practice with sound symbol associations. Some kids needs lots of it! Each time you sort a picture card, your students will repeat the sound and the letter name. When I do a sort like this, I use the newest letter and the last two or three that were taught. That way, they are getting repetition with other letters, too. I’ll also do sorts with similarly sounding letters, like b/ p and t/d. You can tie in letter formation practice by having students write the letter on a white board after it is sorted. 

I have an old blog post about how I teach the alphabet. It’s packed with great tips!

This was a small group activity to do after teaching silent e. I wanted to point out the different ways to spell these sounds. At this point, they had learned about ck vs. k with ending /k/ and that the letter <s> often days /z/ at the end of words. They also learned that <ce> says /s/. 

To do this activity, start with the pocket chart with just the sound headers. Hold up a word or give each student their own notecard with a word to read to the group. Together, decide what sound they hear at the end of the word. Then, highlight the letter or letters that make that sound. If needed review any spelling rules. The next day, you can do this activity with them spelling the words instead of reading them (so in notebooks, they would have three columns with the sound headings and write the words you say under each heading).

This is a super common challenge with consonant blends. The issue is with phonemic awareness. They are struggling with the blending or the segmenting of four sounds, particularly sounds that stick together a little more. 

One thing to add is that often students will improve using this strategy with just isolated words but then they won’t apply it in connected text. Recently I instructed my student try this when he was reading phrasing that contained words with ending blends. It really helped. Another thing to note is that I often have to remind students to repeat what they already read before adding on that last sound. 

When students do omit a sound, I’ll write both words next to each other to compare. For example, I’ll write “sand” and “sad” next to each other and ask my students what is different about the two words. I’ll do the opposite and say both words and ask them what sound is different. I want to make sure they repeat the words themselves because it does help when they hear themselves say it and stretch the sounds. 

I hope this was helpful!

When I’m working on spelling, kids often want to just just jump in and spell the word. But that can lead to errors that may be avoided. It sounds so basic but it’s so important that our students say the word out loud themselves. Here we can check to make sure they can pronounce it clearly and correctly. 

Connecting to meaning is also a necessary step that is so easy to skip. There are three forms of a word: it’s pronunciation (sounds), it’s spelling (orthography) and it’s meaning. We don’t want to overlook this step. 

Stretching the word isn’t always necessary as students become more proficient with spelling in general and as their phoneme segmenting skills improve. However, I find in the beginning, it’s super helpful! 

I recently updated it with the two lines at the bottom for dictation, so if you already downloaded it, you may want to go back and download again for the update. 

I also have a version with a step to check for prefixes and suffixes. This step is super helpful because students are more likely to spell the word correctly if they spell the base word first, then add on the prefix or suffix. There’s also a version for two syllable words.

*Repost*  You all know I love phonology and teaching my students to match phonemes (sounds) to graphemes (symbols). It’s essential that kids have that strong foundation. But that’s just one piece of the spelling puzzle. Morphology plays a huge role. In fact, as students get older, it plays a bigger role than phonology. Even early on, there are some words that can be better explained using morphology. 
*
This is a great example. You can teach your kids that the word “does” is actually base word <do> + suffix <es>. Although the pronunciation isn’t the same, the spelling is intact! The word “done” is also base word <do> and suffix <ne>. This aligns with “go”, “gone”, and “goes”. Again, pronunciation doesn’t match up for “gone” (although it does for “goes”) which makes it appear to be “irregular” but the spelling is consistent. In this case, I feel like morphology makes more sense than matching the sounds /d/ /u/ /z/ to <d> <oe> <s>. When I’m teaching this word, I actually do both! I show students how the phonemes and graphemes match up, then I explain the morphology by pointing out the relationship to “do”. 
*
From here, show students the different words you can make with the base “do” (redo, undo, redoing, redone, undone, undoing, does, done, doing). 
*
Pronunciation changes is common. Think about music, musician, musical. The base spelling is consistent but the pronunciation changes. 
*

This word is pretty straight forward, but I like how it illustrates the difference between letters and graphemes.

Phoneme: The smallest unit of SOUND in a word. 

Graphemes: A Letter or letters that represent a sound. Graphemes can be made up of 1, 2, 3, or 4 letters. (For example, <b> is a grapheme that represents the sound /b/. <ch> is a grapheme that represents the sound /ch/. <igh> is a grapheme that spells the long i sound.) When we are talking about letters, we are referring to the 26 letters of the alphabet. A grapheme can be a single letter, but it can also be a combination of letters. 

Morphemes: the smallest unit of meaning. A word can have one morpheme (just a base word) or several (you can attach prefixes and/or suffixes onto roots or bases). A prefix, suffix, base word and root word are all morphemes. For example, the word uncovered has three morphemes: un-cover-ed. “cover” is a base because it can be a word on its own. The word “unpredictable” has 4 morphemes: prefixes un- and pre-, root <dict >, and suffix -able. Each of these morphemes carry meaning that affects the meaning of the whole word. 

I didn’t include syllables here in this example because in this word it’s the same as the morphemes, but it definitely isn’t always. A syllable is an uninterrupted segment of sound with one vowel sound. Syllables are the beats of a word. In the word “teacher”, there are two vowel sounds, so there are two syllables. In the word “uncovered” there are three syllables:  un-cov-ered. Notice the word is divided differently than if you divide it by morphemes. That’s because syllable division is based on pronunciation and how many vowel sounds are in the word, where as morphology is based on meaning.

I want to note that I’m not using official symbols for sound because I want everyone to be able to understand what I’m showing. (Well, that and I don’t always understand the official symbols myself-ha!) I thought it would be fun to do a word a week so let me know if there’s a word you’d like to see. 

First, I’ll talk about the sounds (phonemes) in this word and how they relate to the graphemes. 

ear: In this word, the letters <ear> represent the /er/ sound. This is a great example to help us see the difference between graphemes and letters. The letters <e>, <a>, and <r> all represent their own sounds, but in this word they together represent one sound. Together, they are a grapheme  <ear> that represents the /er/ sound.

ing: The letters -ing in this word are a suffix. The letters ing can also just be part of a word (like in “ring”). As a suffix, students learn pretty quickly that -ing spells “ing”. This is a suffix that has a consistent pronunciation (many do not). Because the pronunciation of suffixes isn’t always consistent, I don’t like to focus too much on how sounds and symbols match up. However, since –ing is so consistent with pronunciation and is also a string of letters found in base words, I thought it would be worth pointing out how the sounds and graphemes match up. The <i> represents the long e sound and the letters <ng> represent the /ng/ sound. (I’ll leave more notes about ing in the comments.)

Morphology:
The base word is “learn” and the suffix is “ing”. -ing is an inflectional suffix meaning “right now”. In this case, it assigns the tense of the word. (Inflectional suffixes can also show possession or make a word plural for nouns or show comparison for adjectives.) Inflectional suffixes do not change the main meaning or grammatical category/part of speech of a word (nouns stay nouns and verbs stay verbs). 

You can switch out the suffix to make “learner”, “learns”, “learned”. You can also add in prefixes to make “relearn” or “unlearn”. Each of those affixes (prefixes or suffixes) carry their own meaning that slightly changes the meaning of the word, but the base word holds the bulk of the meaning.

Spelling errors can be put into three categories: phonological, orthographic, and morphological. 

With a phonological error, the spelling is phonetically inaccurate. The student may not have heard all of the sounds, or did not match them to the correct letters. In some cases, the student may actually be saying the word incorrectly. An example is “baf ” for “bath”. In other cases, they can say the word correctly, but are struggling to break the word up and all of its own parts. An example of this is writing “wet” for “went”. Finally, they may just be matching the sound to the wrong grapheme. For example, they may write “shop” for “chop”. 

With an orthographic error, it could be that the student heard all of the sounds correctly, but still spelled it inaccurately because they do not know an English spelling generalization or pattern. These errors can make sense because it looks like they “sounded the word out” correctly. These errors are not the result of hearing the sounds incorrectly. In this case, the student hasn’t learned a specific spelling generalization, or phoneme grapheme relationship. A common example is “bak” for “back”. 

Morphologic errors have to do with not having knowledge of morphemes, like prefixes, suffixes, and roots. In the early grades a really common example I see is substituting <t> for the suffix -ed. for older kids it could be spelling “vacashun” for “vacation”.

All of this can inform our instruction!

I made a video showing the ages I went through to create this word matrix. I thought it would be helpful to show how it is a process and when I begin, I don’t actually have the answers. The more I do these, the more I learn about words and morphemes in general.

Word matrices are so helpful in breaking apart morphemes in a word and finding related words with the same root or base. There is definitely a huge learning curve that I’ve been riding for years now. The more I learn and explore words, the more fascinated I get. Now when I’m reading with a student I’ll come across words where I start mentally thinking about the root and wondering about related words. 

This helps with spelling because students are seeing common prefixes and suffixes. It can also help in other ways. For example, if a student finds it difficult to remember that there are two <r>’s in the word “correct”, they can see here that both are needed because one belongs to the root and the other is part of the prefix. I’m more word matrices you do, kids will see common affixes. They will start to be really familiar with -ion and know that it is not spelled <shun>.

This is one of my favorite quotes!

“Sight words” are words that can be read instantly and effortlessly. The goal is to make every word a sight word.

*High-frequency words are words that are most frequently occurring in reading materials. Knowing these words helps students with fluent reading since they are the most commonly used words in texts. Most of these words are fully decodable, some are mostly decodable and some are “irregular”. 

*Irregular Words: These are words that do not have expected letters to represent certain sounds.  Most irregular words have only one unexpected sound-symbol relationship (like ”from”). There are some words that are totally irregular, like “could”, “one”, and “some”. It is important to point out these irregularities to
students so they can understand the structure of the word. This understanding will lead to accurate word recognition.

Other words are considered “irregular” because they may have a letter-sound combination or generalization that has not been taught yet. For example, the word “have” may seem irregular before learning the rule that English words do not end
in <v>, so there is always an <e> following the <v> at the end of a word. The word “play” may also be considered irregular before students learn that the letters <ay> represent the long a sound at the end of words.

*Heart Words: The term “heart words” was created to describe these irregular words because some part of the word will have to be “learned by heart.” When teaching words, teachers instruct students to put a heart above the unexpected sound-symbol relationship. For example, you would put a heart above the letter <o> in “from” to remind students that that part just needs to be “learned by heart.”

The goal is to make every word a “sight word” so that students can recognize them instantly and accurately. This automatic word recognition is the first step toward fluent reading.

Last year I showed this strategy using a card holder but I wanted to show you how to use it with just a piece of paper. (I’ll share the older post in my stories so you can see the card holder.) 
A common problem that I see with beginning meters is that they sound out every. single. word. They sound out the first word, then they move right on to the next word and sound out that word and then they go to the next. By the end of the sentence they have no idea what they’ve read. Any meaning is lost and the exercise becomes more about getting through each word. I model and encourage my students to go back to the beginning of the sentence to reread and get momentum back after they have just paused to decode a word. (If they’ve read a word automatically they don’t need to do that. ) This helps with automatic word recognition, fluency at the sentence level and making sure they get the meaning behind the words. 

You can use this strategy with a sentence strip and a piece of colored paper folded.

This was a fun one! I think this word is interesting when you look at the phonology and it’s interesting looking at morphology. Were you surprised to see that the word education has the same root as introduce? 

Pronunciation: the d ends up sounding like /j/ and the t loses its /t/ sound and sound like /sh/ when combined with i. This happens a lot! Think about the word “trip” and “drop”. They sound like “chrip” and “jrop” right? Sounds can change when they are influenced by their neighboring sounds. I forget what this is called so I need one of my more rememberful (I know that’s not a word but I wish it was) SoR friends to remind me what it’s called. 

There are also two schwas in this word. There are four vowel sounds (creating four syllables) and you can clearly hear two of them but the other two are in the unaccented syllables so we end up making the lazy schwa sound instead of the expected vowel sound (although I’m sure it may be different with a different dialects.)

Morphology: There is so much here! First off, learning that the word education can be broken down further than educate + ion is pretty cool. The fact that it actually has the root “duce” just like introduce and produce is interesting especially when you think about how the sound of the c shifts. 

I made a video breaking this down more.  I explain things like duce and duct being roots that means the same thing (one is used for verbs and the other for nouns/adjectives). I went into the pronunciation, and how the graphemes and  phonemes match up even though it looks like it wouldn’t, and I explained a little more about the word matrix.

In a visual drill students are shown cards with a grapheme on them. (A grapheme is a letter or letters that represent a sound.) Students will quickly say the sound that the grapheme represents. After you learn a new grapheme, you add that new grapheme to your deck to review it each day. 

This is a great way to begin each lesson. It is meant to be quick - it can be done in 1-2 minutes. 

The goal is for students to see a grapheme and instantly say the sound. Automaticity at the sound level is an early step toward developing fluency.  Being automatic with sounds supports decoding.

I love using this chart to help students become more automatic with word recognition. The hope is that they see the common word ending and apply that while decoding.  I also like using this chart for the two other activities I mentioned. It’s like a ready to go resource sitting there waiting to be used when you have a few minutes. My favorite is the one where I ask, “which ending would you use for the word _____?” This really requires a lot of attention to the details of the word and the endings on the chart. Kids are who are more proficient readers can do it easily so they are not my target audience for this. ;) This is more for those kids who don’t make these connections on their own and/or easily. 

A question I usually get is if I teach phonics just using word families and the answer is heck no! This is one supplemental activity but not the basis of my instruction. I first teach kids letter sound relationships and how to blend sounds together to read words. I don’t want to rely on learning “at” in order read other words. When I’m teaching cvc words with short a for example, I don’t want to jump too quick to word endings or overly focus on that as a way to learn to read. I want students attending to every letter and I want them to be able to decode and spell words on their own before introducing the word endings. The last thing I want is them just guessing “rat, sat, fat” without really reading. However, I do want to point out these common endings and help kids make these connections. Students that are receiving intervention often don’t make that connection easily. They are usually the kids that are still sounding out every single sound. So this is a way to help them out a bit. If they can map the word “at” maybe that can help them out when they see a word with that word ending. 

Another question I get is if I use backward decoding (read -at then read “sat”) or successive blending (/s/ / a/…. “Sa”… “saaaat”). My answer is both! It depends on what the student needs. :) 

I hope this is helpful and clear things up. Let me know if you have any questions.

Sometimes kids need a little more repetition to turn a word into a “sight word” (meaning they recognize that word instantly and automatically without needing to decode it). It doesn’t just happen by showing them a word and expecting them to just memorize it. They need to have opportunities to make the connections between pronunciation, meaning, and the orthography (the letter sequence that makes up the written word). This happens when they practice spelling and decoding the word. 

This reel was sped up to show the activity but in real time it starts out much slower. I encourage my students to decode the word at their pace to make sure they are reading the word in front of them and not feeling pressured to guess. After some repetition, the hope is automatic word recognition. For some kids this happens with just a few exposures. For others, it can take a bit longer. Having games like this makes it feel less monotonous!

It’s Dyslexia Awareness Month! 👏Swipe to see common indicators of dyslexia at different ages. 

As teachers, we can’t diagnose but can use screeners like Acadience or DIBELS to identify at-risk students and we can recommend further testing if we think a student may have dyslexia. I know that many districts don’t recognize dyslexia specifically (which is completely unacceptable to me but that’s where we’re at unfortunately😡). This makes things extra challenging for teachers. In a better educational world, every school would have a dyslexia specialist who could do this testing, guide teachers, and provide support for students. 

Connecting with your local Decoding Dyslexia group may be helpful. I think every state has one now. (Decoding dyslexia is a parent led grassroots movement that has created some incredible change in many states. They provide resources and support for families💕.) Another place to look is the International Dyslexia Association @dyslexiaida. 

Overcoming Dyslexia by Sally Shaywitz is one of my favorite professional books ever! She has a course right now on Coursera, too. 

I have worked with many students who have dyslexia over the years, but I am not an expert- I’m just someone trying to spread the word. If you’d like to learn from someone who I consider the expert, check out  @pdxreadingspecialist . She provides excellent training about dyslexia! (There is even an on-demand option.) We’ve worked together in the past and I have to say that I’m her biggest fan! 😍 She is so dynamic and engaging- an all day training flies by! 

Even if you feel like your hands are tied because of how your districts handles things, I think it can still be meaningful and impactful to be an educator who is knowledgeable about dyslexia. 💕🫶💡

#saydyslexia #dyslexiaawareness #dyslexia #iteach #iteachtoo #iteachreading #ortongillingham #structuredliteracy #scienceofreading

More dyslexia info for you! 

Here is the definition from The International Dyslexia Association @dyslexiaida : “Dyslexia is a specific learning disability that is neurobiological in origin.  It is characterized by difficulties with accurate and or fluent word recognition and by poor spelling and decoding abilities. These difficulties typically result from a deficit in the phonological component of language, that is often unexpected in relation to other cognitive abilities and the provision of effective classroom instruction.”

Here are a few tips about how to explicitly teach the digraph <sh>. After introducing the new grapheme <sh>, you’ll want to give your students plenty of time to practice reading and spelling word using that grapheme. Start with words then move up to phrases and sentences and then to a decodable book or passage. Since I teach graphemes after cvc words, I will make sure the sentences mainly just include words that use graphemes or patterns that I’ve taught so far. At the guided practice phase, proving corrective feedback to your students is super important. Take note of any specific difficulties they are having. 

That last activity with word sort is good to do with a small group that needs some extra practice but you could do it whole group, too. This is meant to be a guided activity, not an independent one.

Reading multi-syllable words can feel so daunting! Teaching students how to break words up into smaller chunks is so helpful. One way to do that is to focus on syllables. Another way to do that is to focus on morphemes (smallest unit of meaning including prefixes, suffixes, roots, and base words). This takes time but I’m a strong believer in starting early, sprinkling in snippets here and there. Even if you haven’t explicitly taught these prefixes, you can still point them out to kids. I say, “We keep seeing this syllable over and over in different words. This is actually a common prefix that we will learn more about later. For now we can work on recognizing it and using that to help us break up the word.” We always want to be morpheme detectives! 

I’ve added some ideas for incorporating morphology into my syllable division unit. I also added some ideas and language in there to make the point that syllable division rules are just one way to help break up a word but over-focusing on the right way to divide a word can get tedious and defeats the purpose. I’m trying to make the instruction in that unit emphasize flexibility with decoding multi-syllable words while still being explicit. My goal is for students to have a variety of strategies to decode unknown words. I started doing a lot more of this with my second graders mid-late last year and it was so fun! I really believe I was laying some good ground work there. 

If you’re interested in seeing that unit, type “link” in the comments. If you already own it, you’ll want to check out the updates!

This is one resource I use for letter recognition practice. Full disclosure- these took a while to prep. I didn’t do it all at once. But  now that I have them ready to go, it’s so nice! 

Instead of using these mats, you can recreate the skills we practice in these ways:

* Have students trace the letter on any surface.  They can also just trace in the air. 

* Get some wikki stix or play dough and have your students build the letters. 

* Write a bunch of letters on a white board (with the target letter written several times) and have students find that target letter OR grab a book or magazine and have students look for that letter. 

* Say different words with and without the target sound and have them give a thumbs up if they hear the target sound.

First I introduce the suffix -es by showing when the suffix -s doesn’t work.  I build words ending with s, x, sh, ch, or z and demonstrate how it’s pretty much impossible to pronounce the word just with a suffix -s (the sounds just blend together). 

I talk about how adding suffix -es adds a syllable to the word because of the vowel sound. I also explain that the suffix -es has the same role as suffix -s with nouns and verbs. 

Then I do the pocket chart activity. We say the base word and use it in a sentence. Then I reframe the sentence to force the use of suffix -es or -s. Then, they tell me which is correct. I flip to reveal the correct answer and reinforce the rule of when to use suffix -es vs. -s. 

Next, (usually the next day) we do the opposite. We take the word and practice identifying the suffix and decode the base word. I explain how this is a great way to decode words with suffixes- identify the suffix so you can just focus on the base word first then add it back in.

Last, practice in context. Write a decodable sentence on sentence strips but leave out the suffix. Read the sentence then decide which suffix is correct. After that, reread the sentence. Your students are practicing the new skill while also getting decoding practice. 

Not pictured: spelling practice! It’s so important to do a lot of spelling practice when working with suffixes. I teach my students to say the word, identify the base word and spell that first, then add the suffix on.  This takes a lot of practice. 

For phonemic awareness on those days, we practice breaking apart words into base and suffix. For example, I’ll say “rushes” and students will repeat. Then I’ll ask what the base word is. To scaffold more in the beginning, I’ll say “take away /iz/“ and ask what’s left. I use hand motions, too. This helps solidify understanding of base and suffix and really helps with this habit when spelling! 

Want lesson plans and activities to practice suffixes -s and -es? Type “suffix” in the comments and I’ll message you the link!

Even though the letter y represents so many sounds, we can systematically teach students when to use y to represent each sound. It’s not as overwhelming or confusing when they are taught at different points. I don’t teach them all at once! It’s common to hear the question: “When is y a vowel?” I always answer it by saying explaining that y is a letter that can represent a consonant sound and a vowel sound. When it represents a consonant, we can call it a consonant. When it represents a vowel sound ,we can call it a vowel. It’s all about what sound it is spelling. Letters are simply the print version of sounds. Y sure is busy though!

This is another fun word matrix that you can do earlier than later. The root “ject” is one of those that comes up early right when you start to work on decoding and spelling multi-syllable words. Whenever I teach syllable division, students can start that they see “ject” over and over again (reject, subject, inject, project, object). Although I am teaching syllable patterns, I will also take the opportunity to show them the morphemes (prefixes, suffixes, root) of the words. It’s a great time to show them how these words connect and share meaning and spelling. Then you can grow a word by adding on more morphemes.
