Have you ever wanted to spell “grateful” like “greatful”? I definitely have! But the word grateful has nothing to do with the meaning of “great”. “Great” comes from old English and means “big, tall, stout”, whereas the bound base “grate” comes from the Latin root “gratus” which means “pleasing, thankful”. The root grate is also not all at related the actual word (and free base) “grate”. 

Here’s where I got a little tripped up: the word “gratitude” was confusing to figure out suffixes. I thought it could be “grate” + i (a connecting vowel?) + tude but that only works if -tude is actually a suffix. It turns out -ude is the suffix. (This is similar to how -tion and -ture are often referred to as suffixes when they are final syllables but the suffix is actually -ion and -ure.) I looked up if -ite was a suffix and the <e> would just get dropped. It is, but not usually used in this way. So, if you have another way to do this part of the word matrix, please let me know! 

I was also curious about other words that had “grate” in them, like “immigrate”, migrate, integrate, etc. I didn’t think they did since I couldn’t think of any meaning connection, and sure enough, they are not related at all. They have a totally different root. I think it’s still interesting to check on it anyway though! 

I think this word matrix can be helpful in showing how words are related by meaning. It’s also helpful with spelling because I tend to want to spell these words with a <d> because that’s what I hear (“graditude”). Knowing the bound base “grate” will now help me to never misspell those words again. I can remember “grateful” and “gratitude” are related and I can hear the <t> in grateful. 😉 

These are fun to make with students. I don’t have all the answers (clearly😅😆) and  I end up having to look things up on the spot. But the more I do it, the more I learn and things are getting easier. You end up learning through investigation. And honestly, if it ends up that I broke up the word gratitude incorrectly, I don’t think it hurts anything. 😉

Resources: etymonline and Word Searcher from neilramsden.com.

I love using decodable pyramids! The main benefit is that students can read and reread words in a sentence to help develop automaticity at the word level. When you get to the end of the pyramid, you can word on components of fluency, like phrasing and intonation. 

This reel shows I use these for more than just decoding and fluent practice. You can incorporate basic sentence level comprehension and grammar. 

I really like to talk about the other picture options and why they are not the best match. We talk about what word or words would need to change in order to choose a particular picture. For example, there is a picture of a ship on a mug instead of a chip on a mug. That is one single sound difference in the entire sentence! I also chose two meanings of chip on purpose. Some kids may not know both meanings of chip so this is a great opportunity to talk about multiple meaning words. This shows how we can read a sentence correctly but the meaning of the whole sentence changes when you picture the wrong meaning of chip. Also, one picture would be chip in a mug vs on a mug. This highlights how one little word can also change the whole sentence. 

You can also point out subject and predicate (but you wouldn’t have to use those terms). I explain that you need both parts to make a complete sentence. 

I have a bundle of these pyramids and only the cvc, digraph, blends, and silent e have the picture matching. The others have longer sentences and focus more on scooping and identifying words with the focus pattern.I recently had a request to add one more line for writing, so I just got that done and posted that update.

When students are having a hard time making words “stick”, I try to provide more repetition. A typical learner will need 4-14 exposures to learn a word. A student with dyslexia needs 40+ exposures, depending on how impactful their dyslexia is. (It can be up to 200 repetitions!🤯) When this is the case, I spend more time on high frequency words to try to help those words become “sight words” (words recognized immediately and effortlessly). I wish there was a magic quick solution but the truth is, it can take a ton of time and effort for some kids.

This is a fun root to explore because there are quite a few words that kids will see in social studies or science. 

One reason why it is suggested to spell morphemes instead of pronouncing them is because the pronunciation can change when other morphemes are added. This is the perfect example. <nat> is the root. We could say “nat” but it’s not always pronounced with the short a. Sometimes it is pronounced with a long a. In the word “nature”, the <a> represents the long sound, while in the word “natural” it represents the short sound. This happens all the time with related words that share a root. 

Spelling is consistent with morphemes but pronunciation is not. Emphasis shifts as well.  In the word “national”, the first syllable is emphasized and in the final syllable <al> the <a> is a schwa and you can barely hear it. Then when we add another suffix to make nationality, the <al> syllable is the emphasized/ accented syllable and you clearly hear short a sound. 

Pointing out these shifts in pronunciation can be so helpful to our readers who don’t always make these connections on their own. The more they see this happen and also see how these words are related and build upon a common root, the more flexible they can become while decoding and spelling. 

There are also common suffix changing rules with this matrix. Natural is nat+ure+al but we drop the e from ure because we always drop the e before adding a vowel suffix. This is a rule that is so common. Last year my second grade students would say, “we know, we know, drop the e!” 🤣 

Drop your questions in the comments and I’ll do my best to answer. Morphology is fun once you dive in and start playing with words!

You’ve probably seen my reels on “scooping” with younger students. Phrase-cued reading is the next step for older kids who are reading more complex sentences and passages. The scoops can get sloppy when you have a big paragraph or passage, so this is just a cleaner way to do it. A phrase-cued text is a passage that has the phrase boundaries marked or “cued” for the reader. This is a means to train students to recognize those natural pauses that occur between phrases. 

The slash marks are visual cues for students to signal when to pause. It divides the sentences into meaningful phrases. From a fluency standpoint, it helps our students to have more strategic pacing. From a comprehension standpoint, it helps readers understand the relationship between words within a sentence. Phrases usually each carry a key idea. When we read, it helps to read each phrase (identifying each little idea) to get the full meaning of the sentence and then the text. Since the sentence is broken up into more manageable chunks, readers can (hopefully) process information more quickly and accurately. 

With Phrase-Cued Reading, the teacher is marking the phrase boundaries. The goal is for our students to eventually be able to quickly find the words that go together in a meaningful way within the sentence. I think of phrasing as a way to organize the sentence, which helps readers make sense of the text more efficiently. 

One other fluency perk is that it allows students to slow down a bit.  Hear me out! Sometimes when our slower readers are reading aloud, they are trying so hard to read fluently, that they end up rushing through. We know the goal of fluency isn’t to race through the text, but often students mistakenly think that fast reading is the goal. When they race through the words, all prosody is usually lost and the rushing leads to errors. I think that this slows students down and gives them pausing points to check to make sure that their phrase is correct.  So many benefits to using this scaffold! 

Let me know your questions in the comments. I’m still learning but I’ll do my best to answer!

That line makes me laugh every time. I remember when this movie first came out, I used to say it over and over again. Who knew that fast forward 20 years and I’d love it for another reason- my love for morphology! 

English is morphophonemic which means that both morphology and phonology are equally important. The more I Iearn about morphology, the more curious I get. 

I started a blog post several years ago and kept getting intimidated and overwhelmed so I’d stay then stop then start again and stop. Instead I decided to break it up into three posts. The first post is finished and the second post is close to finished! 

If you’re interested in learning about morphology, comment link and I’ll send you the link to the blog post. 

#morphologysnippet

This is such a great question! Our language is morphophonemic which means both morphology and phonology play a part. English words are made up of phonemes (individual sounds) and morphemes (units of meaning). English spellings represent sounds, syllables, and morphemes. Understanding both components can be so helpful with decoding, spelling, and general reading proficiency. 

When it comes to bigger words, I like to teach syllable division and morphology. Both come in handy. As the words get even bigger, morphology plays a bigger role but you still need both. If we equip your students with both, they have more tools to decode or spell a word. 

Here are some examples: with word “basket”, I would probably break that word up into its syllable parts to make it easier to read or spell. That word has 2 syllables but it is only one morpheme. Applying morphology doesn’t help here but my knowledge of syllables revolving around a vowel does help. Same with the word “garbage”. I would remember that <ar> represents the r-controlled vowel sound /ar/ and that often in a bigger word <age> spells /ij/. Even if I didn’t know that, I’d figure it out when I decoded gar-bage with a long a sound. On the other hand, “reconstructed” is much easier when I am super familiar with the prefixes re- and con- and the suffix -ed. Then I could explore the root <struct> and learn about 20 other words all with the base meaning “to build”. I not only can decode and spell that word by combining 4 morphemes, but I also can grasp the meaning better by understanding the meaning of the morphemes. When I’m spelling the word “really”, I’m going to remember two l’s if I understand that it is base word “real” plus suffix -ly (as opposed to trying to sound the word out). 

I talk more about this in my blog post about morphology. Comment “blog” for that link!
 
#morphologysnippet #structuredliteracy #scienceofreading #sorsnippet

Here’s another morphology concept to teach right away to our kindergarten students. I never put suffixes in sound boxes.  I always prompt students to identify the base word and use phoneme-grapheme mapping to encode the base word first, then add in the suffixes. It’s a good habit to get into. Why?

🧩For one, they are more likely to spell the word correctly. Think about the word “cats”. It’s hard to hear the /t/ in cats but not hard at all to hear in “cat”. That happens a lot! 
🧩Secondly, it helps our students get the idea that suffixes carry meaning or have a job to do (like -ed making things past tense). For affixes (prefixes and suffixes), it’s less about pronunciation and more about the meaning behind them. 
🧩Third, pronunciation doesn’t always match up to spelling when it comes to suffixes. We see this right away with suffix -ed and all of its pronunciations (/d/, /t/, and /id/). It becomes much more pronounced later, as I’ve talked about in other reels. So why not lay this groundwork right away with these simpler words? 

I see so much of morphology instruction in k-1 as laying the groundwork for future, more complicated morphology work to come. I’ve learned through experience that starting this in k-1 makes an enormous difference. They do get it!

This is a visual I’ve used for a while and admittedly it’s  just as much for me as for my students! It keeps me on track and reminds me to focus on different components of fluency. Fluent reading is so much more complex than just reading at a particular rate. Rate is a common way we measure fluency but it is definitely not all there is to it. The components of fluency are accuracy, automaticity (recognizing words instantly), and prosody. Prosody involves a lot of different things including reading with proper phrasing, pausing, intonation (rise and fall of pitch), tone (showing emotion), and (at times) expression.

When I originally posted this a couple years ago, rate was one of the squares on this poster. Then I quickly realized that rate isn’t something you can work on. It’s something that is developed through increased accurate and automatic word recognition. But it’s not really something you can teach or practice in and of itself. The last thing we want is kids trying to read faster than they are capable of. That usually leads to errors and nervous sounding reading. On the flip side we can work on these other things. So I ended up taking out rate and splitting up punctuation and phrasing since they are different and I found myself working on those a lot! There’s a lot more I need to learn about fluency, but I’m here for it! It is a huge challenge for so many students, especially our students with dyslexia. 

Comment “fluency” if you’d like the link to this free resource.

I was inspired by friend Michelle’s post (@michelle_thecolorfulclassroom ) with the word sum for “resolution” that she posted. My curiosity got the best of me so I had to look into it more! Like so many words, the root “resolut” has a variant - “solv”. They both come from the Latin root “solvere” meaning “to loosen”. 

The word “resolution” has two meanings. The first is from the original meaning related to the word “solve” (“loosen” a problem) as in to find a resolution. The meaning as related to a New Year’s resolution came about in the 1500s and is more related to the meaning of “resolve” as in a state of being determined. At least that’s how I interpreted the info I found on etymonline! 😅 A site called Membean had some great information too, explaining that a resolution is being “loosened back from all hinderances of doing something”. 

There’s also some science words here: solution, solvent (I forgot to add suffix -ent), dissolve, solute. These are great because their meanings of “loosen” are more literal than the other others.

This is a more complicated word matrix that you could do with students in the older intermediate/middle grades. 

If you’re looking for how to divide it by syllable (focusing on pronunciation) instead of morpheme (focusing on meaning) , it’s res-o-lu-tion (closed, open, open, final stage syllable).

Okay I know this seems simple and possibly obvious? Hear me out, though. 

First of all, this is for a specific type of student. I use this for students who really really struggle with word recognition. Those are usually our students with dyslexia. You have done the phoneme grapheme mapping several times. You have provided repetition and shown the word within connected text. But still they look at the word as if they’ve never seen it. This activity would be too easy for most of your students but there is always one or more that really struggle to make the words stick. 

These are high frequency words with the VC or CvC pattern. So these are the first HFW that I work with. For students who struggle with word recognition, it is even more important to put  more time into the high frequency words. For the typical student, this activity would be quite easy. They’d quickly be able to point out the word.  But I’ve found that this is a good warmup for my intervention students. You may even find they point to a look alike word. What we’re doing here is having them attend to the letters in the word. Hearing a word and finding it  is much easier that decoding it (similar to how when students are first learning letters it’s easier for them to find the letter you say than it is to retrieve the name or sound on their own). So I do this activity first, then I have them decode the same words. Then I use these words in phrases.  Repetition. 😅

For a small group, you can lay the letters out. Tell your students to find the word with their eyes and look at it. Give a thumbs up when they’ve found it. Then, you hold up the card and point to each letter as they say the sounds. 

I hope all this makes sense! Like I said, it looks super basic and it is, but it may also be just what certain students need.

I’m not big on selfies but I had to show off this shirt from @letsgetliteracy 😍! (Also I wish my hair was not blocking part of this adorable shirt!)

Did you know that 65% of US 4th graders are not reading proficiently? There is also a connection between early literacy and incarceration. Over 70% of inmates in America’s prisons cannot read above fourth grade level. According to the National Assessment of Adult Literacy, 2/3 of students who cannot read proficiently by the end of fourth grade will end up in jail or on welfare. These are scary stats to hear, but it important that we talk about it. 

What can we do? Step one is to educate ourselves. This takes time and can feel overwhelming but it’s so worth it. I don’t know about you, but I was not prepared to be a teacher after graduating from college. Then, like many of us,  I was guided  to do literacy instruction the wrong way! 😳 I’ve been steadily trying to “be better” now that I “know better”. 

Literacy is a civil right for every child. When I wear this shirt, my hope is to generate conversations with people and spread awareness. Thank you to Catie for sending it to me!

Letter formation is important. Good letter formation helps students write fluently. If they don’t have to think about how to write the letter they can focus on other things like how to spell and more importantly, content. Writing letters the opposite way can make writing less fluid. (Think about a student who adds an extra pencil stroke or two when forming a letter because they started in the wrong spot.) 

I always want to spend time on handwriting if my students are still not forming their letters correctly or if they’re not automatic with that letter formation. Since there’s always so much to cover, sometimes it’s helpful to integrate handwriting in with other things. Don’t get me wrong, handwriting deserves its own time sometimes too. Explicit instruction with handwriting is essential. However, once I’ve taught it, and I’m looking to give more practice, this is a way to do it.

I’ve updated my syllable division posters and practice pages to reflect what I’ve been learning and working on with my own students. I first created this several years ago and I had so much more to learn. It was really helpful at the time, but after years of implementing in my classroom, I’ve evolved to include more morphology. I still use syllable division, but not as rigidly. This update shows how I teach now. 

With multi words, it’s best to be flexible. Now I tell my students that the first thing I do is check for common prefixes and suffixes. You will often find one! From there determine if you need to keep breaking the word down or if that did the trick. For example, in the word invent, there is the common prefix in. After I circled the prefix in, then I see there’s only one vowel left in the rest of the word. So there’s no more syllable division necessary. If there are no prefixes or suffixes, then I look for the vowels and I go through the syllable, division steps. 

One really important thing though is to teach our students to be flexible with vowel sounds.  For example, if they start with a short sound and the word doesn’t make sense then they can try the long sound or even the schwa sound. Practicing this in a guided setting is key! Model, practice, model again, more practice. 

Although I teach morphemes explicitly, you do not need to explicitly teach every morpheme before pointing them out to your students. For example, it’s common to see the prefixes “con” and “com” in several two syllable words. I make sure my students look out for those because they will know that is one syllable right away. Much quicker and easier! I teach that strategy long before I go into detail about those prefixes, its meaning, how’s they’re used with various roots, and the fact that they are assimilated prefixes . Point is, for the purpose of decoding and spelling, I can hold off on all that and just teach my students that these are common prefixes and  are the first syllable in many words. 

Comment “link” to learn more or if you already own this, to download the update. I’ll be posting some more examples of this as well. (I also have another unit coming!)

An assimilated prefix is a prefix that changes spelling, depending on the first letter of the route or base that it is attaching to. Some people call them chameleon prefixes there are seven assimilated prefixes, including ad-, con (com, cor, col) dis (di, dif), ex (ef, ec), in (im, ir , il), ob (op, of, oc) and sub (sus, suc , sur, sup). 

I’ve been working on making word matrices for the past couple of years and these pop up all the time. Admittedly, it’s taken me a while to figure it all out! 😅🤪 
 
I hope this is helpful. Keep those questions coming!

To get this definition of fluency, I merged my favorite definitions together. This mainly comes from Hudson, Mercer, & Lane (2000), and Louise Spear-Swerling (2022,) 

I love that this definition for many reason, but here are my top 3 reasons:
*It illustrates the components of fluency: accuracy (reading words correctly), automaticity (reading words automatically without sounding out- this leads to increased rate), and prosody (reading with proper phrasing, intonation, stress, and at times expression). 
*It includes the ultimate goal of reading which is comprehension. During the past year, I’ve been diving deep into research about fluency  and something I started to realize was that it all comes back to comprehension.  Fluency isn’t the goal- it’s a means to get there. 
*I love the adjectives here. (1) CONVERSATIONAL rate emphasizes that fluency isn’t about speed reading. We want our students rate to be such that it sounds like speech. Why? Well two reasons: First, it opens up space to focus on meaning and not the words. But second, if it sounds like speech, we are more likely to make meaning. Again, we’re back to comprehension. (2) APPROPRIATE prosody: Sometimes I text doesn’t call for theatrical expression, so it’s not about having expression while we read. Prosody is more about our natural intonation and pauses. Again, we are looping back to meaning. When we read a sentence in meaningful phrases, we are showing that we understand that sentence. When our voice rises and falls at the right times, that impacts the meaning of the sentence as well. (3) DEEP understanding: I sort of already covered this one, but because it’s important I’ll reiterate that when we fully comprehend something, we read it in a certain way. This is reciprocal: If we guide students to find meaningful phrases, encourage them to attend to all punctuation, and discuss the tone of the text, we will help them comprehend what they are reading. 

For a link to an old post about fluency and automaticity, comment “fluency”.
